Package gov.sandia.gmp.util.numerical.lbfgs

Class LBFGS

java.lang.Object
gov.sandia.gmp.util.numerical.lbfgs.LBFGS
All Implemented Interfaces:
Serializable
public class LBFGS extends Object implements Serializable
Limited-Memory Quasi-Newton Approximation employing the limited-memory Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno (LBFGS) algorithm for large-scale multidimensional unconstrained minimization problems.

This file is a translation of Fortran code written by Jorge Nocedal.

LBFGS is distributed as part of the RISO project. Following is a message from Jorge Nocedal: 

   From: Jorge Nocedal [mailto:nocedal@dario.ece.nwu.edu]
   Sent: Friday, August 17, 2001 9:09 AM
   To: Robert Dodier
   Subject: Re: Commercial licensing terms for LBFGS?
   
   Robert:
   The code L-BFGS (for unconstrained problems) is in the public domain.
   It can be used in any commercial application.
   
   The code L-BFGS-B (for bound constrained problems) belongs to
   ACM. You need to contact them for a commercial license. It is
   algorithm 778.
   
   Jorge
This code is derived from the Fortran program lbfgs.f. The Java translation was effected mostly mechanically, with some manual clean-up; in particular, array indices start at 0 instead of 1. Most of the comments from the Fortran code have been pasted in here as well.

The most recent version removes the necessity to exit the function to call the function optimization and gradient evaluation, or the inverse Hessian diagonal estimation function. These are now called via an interface (LBFGSFunction) which can be used to define the function evaluations externally without the need of recalling this function many times. Additionally, the code has been restructured to place many, otherwise non-static variables into a local functional context when possible. If variables could not be defined locally they were changed to private non-static values as were the functions so that many of the LBFGS objects could be made to operate simultaneously in a distributed parallel environment. Finally, some code clean-up was performed to remove the extraneous "-1" from array indices and to change the accompanying "for" loop index to run from 0 to n-1 instead of 1 to n.

Here's some information on the original LBFGS Fortran source code, available at http://www.netlib.org/opt/lbfgs_um.shar. This info is taken verbatim from the Netlib blurb on the Fortran source.

        file    opt/lbfgs_um.shar
        for     unconstrained optimization problems
        alg     limited memory BFGS method
        by      J. Nocedal
        contact nocedal@eecs.nwu.edu
        ref     D. C. Liu and J. Nocedal, ``On the limited memory BFGS method for
        ,       large scale optimization methods'' Mathematical Programming 45
        ,       (1989), pp. 503-528.
        ,       (Postscript file of this paper is available via anonymous ftp
        ,       to eecs.nwu.edu in the directory pub/lbfgs/lbfgs_um.)
Author:
Jorge Nocedal: original Fortran version, including comments (July 1990). Robert Dodier: Java translation, August 1997. Jim Hipp: Java functional interface for optimization function and gradient evaluation and overall code restructuring to remove the necessity to exit the function to call optimization and diagonal set functions, March 2008.

    • LBFGS

      public LBFGS()
      Default constructor.

  • Method Details

    • setLBFGSFunction

      public void setLBFGSFunction(LBFGSFunction li)
      Sets the object that implements the function and gradient, and diagonal Hessian estimate functions.
      Parameters:
      li - The implementor of the function and gradient, and if defined, the diagonal Hessian estimate functions. This object is used by the lbfgs functions that do not explicitly define a LBFGSFunction object as an input argument.

    • getErrorCode

      public int getErrorCode()
      Returns the error code at the completion of the lbfgs call.
      Returns:
      The error code.

    • setCorrectionCount

      public void setCorrectionCount(int m)
      Sets the number of kept corrections to be used by the lbfgs.
      Parameters:
      m - The number of kept corrections.

    • setOutputOff

      public void setOutputOff()
      Turns off all output.

    • setOutputFirstAndLast

      public void setOutputFirstAndLast()
      Outputs only the first and last iteration results.

    • setOutputCount

      public void setOutputCount(int cnt)
      Sets the output frequency to every cnt iterations.

    • setOutputAmountOff

      public void setOutputAmountOff()
      Turns off all output

    • setOutputAmountBasic

      public void setOutputAmountBasic()
      Sets the amount of output to the basic amount

    • setOutputAmount

      public void setOutputAmount(int amt)
      Specifies the amount of output generated:

      • amt = 0: iteration count, number of function evaluations, function value, norm of the gradient, and steplength,
      • amt = 1: same as amt=0, plus vector of variables and gradient vector at the initial point,
      • amt = 2: same as amt=1, plus vector of variables,
      • amt = 3: same as amt=2, plus gradient vector.

    • nfevaluations

      public int nfevaluations()
      This method returns the total number of evaluations of the objective function since the last time LBFGS was restarted. The total number of function evaluations increases by the number of evaluations required for the line search; the total is only increased after a successful line search.

    • setAccuracyTolerance

      public void setAccuracyTolerance(double tol)
      Sets the accuracy with which the solution is to be found (defaults to 1.0e-6). The subroutine terminates when 
                  ||G|| < tol * max(1,||X||),
      where ||.|| denotes the Euclidean norm.
      Parameters:
      tol - Input accuracy.

    • getSearchCurvatureTolerance

      public double getSearchCurvatureTolerance()

    • setSearchCurvatureTolerance

      public void setSearchCurvatureTolerance(double lscrvtol)
      Controls the accuracy of the line search mcsrch curvature condition. If the function and gradient evaluations are inexpensive with respect to the cost of the iteration (which is sometimes the case when solving very large problems) it may be advantageous to set gtol to a small value. A typical small value is 0.1. Restriction: gtol should be greater than 1e-4 (ftol).
      Parameters:
      lscrvtol - Line search curvature tolerance condition.

    • setSearchDecreaseTolerance

      public void setSearchDecreaseTolerance(double dtol)
      Internal tolerance for the sufficient decrease condition. Used by the the line search routine, msrch, which attempts to minimize the function along a search direction. This parameter can be set to a different value but should be larger than the requested accuracy (eps) and smaller than the line search curvature tolerance (gtol).
      Parameters:
      dtol - Line search decrease tolerance condition.

    • setMaxFEVPerIteration

      public void setMaxFEVPerIteration(int mfev)
      Sets the maximum allowable function evaluations per inverse Hessian estimate. If this value is exceeded an error is thrown.
      Parameters:
      mfev - Maximum allowable function evaluations per inverse Hessian estimate.

    • lbfgs

      public void lbfgs(double[] x) throws LBFGSException
      Standard call to the lbfgs function. The LBFGSFunction setDiagonal is not used with this call. The internal LBFGSFunction function must have been set with a call to setLBFGSFunction or an error will be thrown
      Parameters:
      x - The initial input vector for which a minimum will be sought.
      Throws:
      LBFGSException

    • lbfgs

      public void lbfgs(double[] x, LBFGSFunction fi) throws LBFGSException
      Standard call to the lbfgs function. The LBFGSFunction setDiagonal is not used with this call.
      Parameters:
      x - The initial input vector for which a minimum will be sought.
      fi - The LBFGSFunction to be used for the object function call.
      Throws:
      LBFGSException

    • lbfgsEstDiag

      public void lbfgsEstDiag(double[] x) throws LBFGSException
      Standard call to the lbfgs function that uses a user defined guess to the inverse Hessian diagonal at each iteration. The diagonal must be supplied by the LBFGSFunction setDiagonal function. The internal LBFGSFunction function must have been set with a call to setLBFGSFunction or an error will be thrown
      Parameters:
      x - The initial input vector for which a minimum will be sought.
      Throws:
      LBFGSException

    • lbfgsEstDiag

      public void lbfgsEstDiag(double[] x, LBFGSFunction fi) throws LBFGSException
      Standard call to the lbfgs function that uses a user defined guess to the inverse Hessian diagonal at each iteration. The diagonal must be supplied by the LBFGSFunction objects (fi) setDiagonal function.
      Parameters:
      x - The initial input vector for which a minimum will be sought.
      fi - The LBFGSFunction to be used for the object function and diagonal calls.
      Throws:
      LBFGSException
